image_2.description: Word embedding is a technique used to convert word sequences into dense semantic vectors, which is utilized in the Title Encoder to learn news representations from news titles.
A component in the model that processes news topics and converts them into numerical vectors for analysis, used to learn news representations from its topics.
A component in the model that processes news subtopics and converts them into numerical vectors for analysis, used to learn news representations from its subtopics.
The broader category or main theme of a piece of news, which is input into the Topic Embedding component and used to label news articles on platforms like MSN News.
The specific subject or theme of a piece of news, which is input into the Subtopic Embedding component and used for news article categorization under broader topics like Sports.

The headline or title of a piece of news, which is processed by the Word Embedding component to extract word-level information and is part of the Title Encoder's role in learning news representations.

CNN Network is part of the Title Encoder, used to learn contextual word representations by capturing local context information, and is also utilized in the News Encoder framework to capture contextual word representations.
STUR stands for Short-Term User Representation model, which uses a GRU network to learn short-term user representations from recent browsing data and capture user's temporal interests.
LTUR refers to the Long-Term User Representation module, which is part of the user encoder system for learning user representations from their IDs and captures user's consistent preferences.
LSTUR approach refers to the Long-Short Term User Representation approach, a framework for user and news representation that includes both long- and short-term user representations.

image_3.description: GRU (Gated Recurrent Units) is a type of recurrent neural network used in both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con architectures to process sequences of data, as well as in the STUR module to learn short-term user representations based on recent browsing news.

News Encoder is a component used in both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con architectures to encode news articles into a vector representation, and is also a part of the LSTUR approach, responsible for learning representations of news from titles, topics, and subtopics.

The sequence of news articles that a user has clicked on, used as input in both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con architectures, and is part of the process for learning user representations in news recommendation services.

The news article being evaluated for recommendation, used as input in both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con architectures, and is the content that users interact with in the context of online news recommendation services.

A vector representation of a user's preferences, used in the LSTUR-con architecture, and is also used to capture user IDs to learn long-term representations of users to capture their consistent preferences.

LSTUR (Long-Short Term User Representation) is the neural news recommendation approach that includes both long- and short-term user representations, and involves frameworks for user and news representation, including LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con architectures.

image_4.description: LSTUR is a news recommendation approach that outperforms baseline methods by capturing both long-term preferences and short-term interests of users. It refers to a method that captures complex and diverse user interests in news reading by using attention mechanism in the news encoder to select important words, helping learn more informative news representations.

Model training refers to the process of training the news recommendation model using user and news representations. It involves using various techniques such as negative sampling, dropout, and GloVe embeddings for word initialization, with the goal of improving the performance of the approach.

News recommendation services are online platforms that provide personalized news recommendations to users. They utilize models trained on user interactions with news articles to predict user preferences and interests.

User representations are learned models that capture the consistent preferences (long-term) and temporal interests (short-term) of online users in the context of news reading. They are crucial for personalized news recommendation systems.
Performance evaluation metrics include AUC, MRR, and nDCG, which are impression-based ranking metrics used to assess the effectiveness of the news recommendation model.
Negative sampling is a technique used in model training where unclicked news articles are used as negative samples to balance the dataset and improve the learning process.

image_6.description: LSTUR-CON is a model that uses the concatenation of both short-term and long-term user representations for news recommendation, represented by a dark green bar in the graph. It is more stable than LSTUR-INI and outperforms baseline methods.

LSTUR-INI is a model that focuses on either long-term or short-term user representations for news recommendation, represented by a teal bar in the graph. It achieves comparable performance to LSTUR-CON.

LTUR is a long-term user representation model used for news recommendation, represented by a yellow bar in the graph. It is useful for news recommendation but can have weak performance when long-term representations are unavailable.

STUR is a short-term user representation model used for news recommendation, represented by a green bar in the graph. It can outperform the LTUR model and is useful for learning short-term user representations from recently browsed news articles.

GRU is used in the STUR model to learn short-term user representations from recent browsing news, represented by a teal bar in the second graph. It achieves better performance than LSTM, probably due to fewer parameters and lower risk of overfitting.
AUC, or Area Under the Curve, is a metric used to evaluate the performance of the models, represented by a yellow bar in the second graph. It is an impression-based ranking metric.
NDCG@10, or Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain at 10, is another metric used to evaluate the performance of the models, represented by a metric in the evaluation.

Attention is a method that uses the summation of news representations weighted by their attention weights, represented by a green bar in the second graph. It is used in encoders based on CNN and LSTM to select important words for learning more informative news representations.

LSTM is a sequence-based encoder used in the STUR model for learning short-term user representations and can replace GRU, represented by a dark green bar in the second graph. It is associated with the development by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber.

image_7.description: LSTM is a sequence-based encoder used in the STUR model for learning short-term user representations and can replace GRU. It is associated with the development by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber.

LSTM+Att is a variant of the news title encoder that includes an attention mechanism, enhancing the performance of LSTM by selecting important words for learning more informative news representations.
CNN refers to a method using convolutional neural networks with max pooling for learning news representations, used as a baseline.
CNN+Att is a news encoder that combines a CNN network and an attention network, showing better performance than other variants in learning news representations.

LSTUR-ini is a proposed method for learning short-term user representations, achieving comparable performance to LSTUR-con, and is one of the methods used in the study to randomly mask long-term user representation in model training.

LSTUR-con is a proposed method for learning long-term user representations, achieving comparable performance to LSTURini and outperforming baseline methods. It uses the concatenation of both short-term and long-term user representations for news recommendation and is another method used in the study to randomly mask long-term user representation in model training.
AUC, or area under the ROC curve, is an impression-based ranking metric used to evaluate the performance of the model, depicted in graph (a).
NDCG@10 is the normalized discounted cumulative gain at 10 metric, depicted in graph (b), and is an impression-based ranking metric used to evaluate the performance of the model.

image_8.description: LSTUR-INI is a model that focuses on either long-term or short-term user representations for news recommendation, used in the context of evaluating performance metrics such as AUC and nDCG@10.

LSTUR-CON is a model that uses the concatenation of both short-term and long-term user representations for news recommendation, used in the context of evaluating performance metrics such as AUC and nDCG@10.

AUC, or area under the ROC curve, is an impression-based ranking metric used to evaluate the performance of the model, including the performance of different configurations of LSTUR-INI and LSTUR-CON.

nDCG, or normalized discounted cumulative gain, is an impression-based ranking metric used to evaluate the performance of the model, including the performance of different configurations of LSTUR-INI and LSTUR-CON at rank 10.

image_9.description: Mask Probability refers to the probability p in Eq. (6) for randomly masking long-term user representation in model training, represented on the x-axis of the graph ranging from 0.0 to 0.9.
